title: Car Dealership
question_text:
A car dealership manager has to routinely examine data as part of his job. On his day off, one of his sales team members dropped off this chart on his desk.
What should be the manager's best guess as to what the sales team member was trying to communicate?

choices.text: The color distribution of the most recent sales.
The average price of the cars the sales team recently sold.
The different types of cars sold during the most recent week.
Which sales team member sold the most cars last week.
The average color of car sold last week.

solution:
Solution

The data given to the manager is representing in a bar chart. There is not much data given in the graph, other than the color of a car. (For reference, we do not suggest that you create a graph without a title, or some context!)

Since the graph only shows the color of the car, we believe that the sales team member is trying to communicate the color distribution of the most recent car sales.

Choice 'A' is correct.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect. Since the manager is not given the sales prices of the cars sold, we cannot find the average sales price.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. The graph only represents color of the car, it does not communicate the type or model of car sold.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. The graph does not mention any members of the sales team, just color of car.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. Since color is not a numeric value, we cannot find the average of the data points.
